definition:
The linear differential equation
$$\frac{d^2f}{dz^2}-2z\frac{df}{dz}+2nf \;=\; 0,$$ in which $n$ is a
real , is called the [*Hermite equation*]{}. Its general solution is
$f := Af_1\!+\!Bf_2$ with $A$ and $B$ arbitrary and the functions $f_1$
and $f_2$ presented as\
$f_1(z) \;:=\; z+\frac{2(1-n)}{3!}z^3+\frac{2^2(1-n)(3-n)}{5!}z^5+
\frac{2^3(1-n)(3-n)(5-n)}{7!}z^7+\ldots\!,$\
$f_2(z) \;:=\; 1+\frac{2(-n)}{2!}z^2+\frac{2^2(-n)(2-n)}{4!}z^4+
\frac{2^3(-n)(2-n)(4-n)}{6!}z^6+\ldots$\
It’s easy to check that these power series satisfy the differential
equation. The coefficients $b_\nu$ in both series obey the recurrence
$$b_\nu \;=\; \frac{2(\nu\!-\!2\!-\!n)}{\nu(nu\!-\!1)}b_{\nu\!-\!2}.$$
Thus we have the
$$R \;=\; \lim_{\nu\to\infty}\left|\frac{b_{\nu-2}}{b_\nu}\right| \;=\; 
\lim_{\nu\to\infty}\frac{\nu}{2}\!\cdot\!\frac{1\!-\!1/\nu}{1\!-\!(n\!+\!2)/\nu} \;=\; \infty.$$
Therefore the series converge in the whole complex plane and define
entire functions.

If the $n$ is a non-negative integer, then one of $f_1$ and $f_2$ is
simply a polynomial function. The polynomial solutions of the Hermite
equation are usually normed so that the highest is $(2z)^n$ and called
the Hermite polynomials.
